page.title: 14LOCAL HISTORY, PURTON STOKE.
page.content: In {Prehistory Times}the area around Purton Stoke and to the west was covered by large dense forests of damp oak wood with thick brambly undergrowth and marshes at the lower levels. A track which crosses the . River key by means of the slab stone bridge, was part of an ancient white way in use for transporting salt from the north to Avebury and Stonehenge. By the end of the{6c}the{Saxons}had colonised this area and settled in farming communities.Purton Stoke, Bentham, and Hayes Knoll were part of the territory called the Hundred of Staple in the Kingdom of Wessex. One of the routes to Malmesbury in {Danish times}was via Purton Stoke Bridge through the forest. We could find no mention of Purton Stoke in the Domesday translation.
